Author: Timo#5756
Content: Why would it fail that if I only have it false by 0.99%?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what happens?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, 0.99% you are okl

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is a 2% attack

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: bias by +1% then by -1%, but this is mitigated by 51% correlation

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: still possible if you sustain 51% attack for days

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and you get to bias prices by 1%

Author: Timo#5756
Content:
Okay, I would agree that this would be secure enough for a lot of use cases. But in no way more secure than Chainlink with aggregation+reputation+stake+TEE.
It's really clever binding the volatility to the blocks, limiting it, it is elegant. My first question I had after reading the article was, what is with other types of data than can't fluctuate by 1%? Like weather data that changes a lot more or completely non-numeric ones?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: use logarithms

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: prices do change by more than 1%, in such a case there is an exeption that allows a 1% change and in 10 blocks it is changed by 10%

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so as long as things arent changing by 50% all the time, it will work, with a delay

Author: Timo#5756
Content: Yeah but now I need something that can mirror price changes by 50% to 1000% for example

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: like duke said, use logaritms to reduce the dynamic range

Author: Timo#5756
Content: Is there a way to use Komodo Oracles or are they not made for non-price use cases?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: or you can change the 1% tolerance level to a different amount

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but that will prevent detecting false data if it is too big

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for non-numeric things as long as it is just one valid answer, then all the nodes would require that specific answer

Author: Timo#5756
Content: But I would have to change the whole consensus rule of the oracle chain. I still need the 1% rule for my price-data use cases

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, we are all about making custom consensus (CC) here

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can have dozens of different consensus rules, each applying to a specific type of tx

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
and we can have as many secure chains  as we want here in Komodo Platform with dPoW

A new chain for every application

Author: Timo#5756
Content: Yeah but the only thing making the price 'true' is the 1% rule. If we can't apply it to non-numeric data, how can we now detect the true and false data? Only by democratic game theory? I could Sybil attack it then

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you mean true/false oracle?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that would be easiest as there is no variance that needs to be handled

Author: Timo#5756
Content: @gcharang Yeah I understand that one. Besides other cryptos, having weak hashpower or centralized stakes, Komodo is kinda linked to the BTC chain and getting the security of that hashpower in some way. I don't know how exactly it works but I heard about it. Thats cool

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it doesnt matter how many miners you have or nodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if the data is invalid, it is rejected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: like trying to use a timestamp from tomorrow

Author: Timo#5756
Content: I'm gonna use a chain that is for non-numeric data. And I see there are currently 50 nodes live. Now I'm gonna spin up 100 and feed wrong data into. What prevents me from that?

Author: Timo#5756
Content: Who says it's invalid?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: lets change this to discuss timestamp to make it more concrete, ok?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you are the attacker and you want to convince the network that your timestamp is the right one

Author: Timo#5756
Content: Timestamp is a different thing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: why?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is data from outside world

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each node has a local system clock

Author: Timo#5756
Content: Sorry, thought about block number not timestamp... lol

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so you want to convince the network it is actually one hour from now, ok?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: try your attack

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all the nodes are checking incoming timestamps to be no more than 1 minute from the future, relative to local system clock

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anything else is rejected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: any node that does this too much is banned

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can have 1 million nodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all one hour ahead

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: attack!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what do you submit to the network

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: the lying miner who won't be getting his block reward

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: miner of invalid data doesnt get to mine the block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no, but if they persist they get banned

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and no node will interact with it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: still waiting for attack... since no attacker block an honest miner mined a valid timestamp

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to attack this you need to change the local system clocks on all the nodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is so simple, anybody can tell it is resistant to bad data. there is no complex interaction of reputation, rewards, punishments

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: frontrunning, freeloading

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all that complexity goes out the window

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: replaced by each node comparing all data with their local version

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: seems Timo left us, i guess his attack against this was to leave?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there are timewarp attacks, which involve biasing the timestamp forward and backward within allowed limits to game the mining difficulty

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and similarily the data can be biased +/-1% here, which is an issue and maybe the tolerance should be lowered to 0.5%, but that slows down the adapting to the real price changes of 10% or more and maybe we get more local nodes rejecting what is valid
